text: Types and Prevalence of Trauma among Youthcription 1
label: H4

text: Human Caused Disasters: accidents, wars, displacement
label: H4

text: Interpersonal Violence: abuse, neglect, domestic violence
label: H4

text: Sudden or anticipated loss of loved one
label: H4

text: Historical Trauma: The collective and cumulative trauma experienced by a
label: H4

text: particular group across generations still bearing the effects.
label: H4

text: Racial Trauma or Race-based Traumatic Stress: Potentially traumatic
label: HH3

text: experiences related to race may include:
label: H4

text: direct experiences of racial harassment including threats of harm or injury
label: H4

text: witnessing racial violence towards other people of color and other ethnicities
label: H4

text: such as hate crimes, violence by law enforcement;
label: H4

text: experiencing discrimination and institutional racism often in the form of racial
label: H4

text: slurs, being followed in a store, communications that convey rudeness.
label: H4

text: Youth may experience these in school or in other community settings.
label: H4

text: In community samples, more than two thirds of students
label: H4

text: in the U.S. report experiencing trauma by age 16, such as
label: H4

text: a serious accident, natural disaster, or experiencing or
label: H4

text: Approximately two out of three children have been
label: H4

text: exposed to violence, crime, and abuse in their homes or
label: H4

text: 50% of youth report more than one form of victimization.
label: H4

text: Youth of color ages 12 to 19 are victims of violent crime more than
label: H4

text: - 3x more likely to be victims of of a robbery.
label: H4

text: - 5x more likely to be victims of a homicide.
label: H4

text: Homicide is the leading cause of death among youth of color ages 15
label: H4

text: Youth of color living in poverty are at increased risk for trauma,
label: H4

text: African American youth living in urban, low-income communities are
label: H4

text: more at risk of exposure to violence than any other population in the
label: H4

text: Impact of trauma on families, communities, and systems
label: H4

text: Human Stress Responsefor your own subheadline
label: H4

text: Fear, anxiety, and worry about continued danger
label: H4

text: Feelings of sadness, guilt, shame, anger, responsibility, embarrassment
label: H4

text: Concern about how others will view them
label: H4

text: Triggers: Reminders of past traumatic experiences that automatically cause
label: HH3

text: the body to react as if the traumatic event is happening again in that moment.
label: H4

text: Hand or body gestures that appear threatening
label: H4

text: Impact of Trauma on Youth subheadline
label: H4

text: Relationships: Difficulty trusting others and forming safe, healthy
label: H4

text: managing feelings. Always on alert for threat.
label: H4

text: Behavior: Easily set off by others or the environment (especially if
label: H4

text: reminded of previous trauma). Responses are extreme ranging from
label: H4

text: aggression to withdrawal. Trouble following rules or guidelines; reactive
label: H4

text: Youth exposed to trauma are more likely to be suspended or
label: H4

text: Cognition: More difficulties with activities related to learning.
label: H4

text: Traumatized youth have poorer academic performance, increased risk
label: H4

text: of failing, poorer test scores, and higher rates of referral to special
label: H4

text: Dissociation: Disconnection from the present moment as a way to
label: H4

text: manage overwhelming stress. Blocking out difficult thoughts and
label: H4

text: feelings often means blocking out most feelings, including positive
label: H4

text: Self-Concept and Future Orientation: Low self-esteem and poor self-
label: H4

text: image are common. Lacking a sense of hope and control over the
label: H4

text: future making goal setting seem pointless.
label: H4

text: Community violence exposure among urban youth is associated with
label: H4

text: higher rates of post-traumatic stress, depressive symptoms, anxiety,
label: H4

text: Youth victimization increases likelihood of becoming a perpetrator of
label: H4

text: violent crimes including intimate partner violence; drug use; and
label: H4

text: 90% of juvenile justice-involved youth have experienced trauma, often
label: H4

text: multiple traumas from an early age.
label: H4

text: 96% of adolescent psychiatric inpatients have histories of exposure to
label: H4

text: More than 70% of adolescents in substance abuse treatment have a
label: H4

text: Parents with histories of and/or current exposure to trauma are at increased risk
label: H4

text: for a number of challenges including:
label: H4

text: Negative or unsafe interpersonal patterns such abuse, neglect, and domestic
label: H4

text: violence that become the source of trauma for youth.
label: H4

text: Difficulty trusting others and building relationships with community providers and
label: H4

text: educators, which impacts their child’s ability to trust other adults.
label: H4

text: Feelings of embarrassment, shame, fear, or guilt about getting outside support
label: H4

text: for their children that may result in negative interactions with
label: H4

text: Mistrust of systems that have contributed to traumatic experiences.
label: H4

text: Consider current societal and institutional factors and inequalities that increase
label: H4

text: risk of trauma for families of color:
label: H4

text: A disproportionate number of children and families live in poverty.
label: H4

text: Living in poverty is accompanied by stressors that can be traumatic and can
label: H4

text: increase risk for multiple exposures to trauma, particularly violent trauma.
label: H4

text: Ongoing experiences of racial trauma/Race-based traumatic stress.
label: H4

text: Mistrust in social institutions (schools, education, government) that impacts
label: H4

text: Combined historical and contemporary trauma without the opportunity to heal
label: H4

text: has detrimental effects on communities of color as a whole.
label: H4

text: Lower self-esteem, feelings of hopelessness and depression, self-
label: H4

text: Increased anger and violence towards self, others, and members of one’s
label: H4

text: Internalized racism – learned helplessness, distorted concept of self,
label: H4

text: disconnection or aversion to things related to your own cultural/ethnic group.
label: H4

text: Direct exposure to trauma: Community providers and educators may bring
label: H4

text: their own histories of trauma to their work or experience trauma on the job.
label: H4

text: Secondary Traumatic Stress: Individuals who work with highly traumatized
label: H4

text: groups are at risk of being indirectly traumatized as a result of hearing about
label: H4

text: another person’s trauma and witnessing its negative effects.
label: H4

text: Vicarious Trauma: Changes in a helper’s inner experience over time as a
label: H4

text: result of responsibility for an empathic engagement with traumatized clients.
label: H4

text: Impact of Trauma on Youth-Serving Systems
label: H4

text: Students exposed to trauma are more likely to escalate and act out.
label: H4

text: Adults may misunderstand and mislablel student behaviors.
label: H4

text: Adults may become increasingly crisis-driven, reactive, and punitive to maintain
label: H4

text: Difficult to maintain a safe environment most conductive to learning.
label: H4

text: Schools risk re-traumatizing students by creating environments and situations that
label: H4

text: mirror or replicate other trauma that students have experienced.
label: H4

text: Impact of Trauma on Youth-Serving Systems
label: H4

text: Traumatized systems respond similarly to traumatized individuals, which
label: H4

text: creates an environment that perpetuates trauma responses.
label: H4

text: Resilience: Positive, adaptive response to significant adversity.
label: HH3

text: Combined environmental and individual factors that help children achieve positive
label: H4

text: outcomes in the face of adversity include:
label: H4

text: The availability of at least one stable, caring, and supportive relationship with an
label: H4

text: A sense of mastery over life circumstances.
label: H4

text: Strong social and emotional skills such as problem-solving, self-awareness, self-
label: H4

text: regulation, and relationship skills that can be supported in school and community
label: H4

text: Environments that are safe, engaging, and supportive.
label: H4

text: Why is a trauma-informed approach critical to supporting youth?
label: H4

text: What are the core components of a trauma-informed approach?
label: H4

text: Adopting a Trauma-Informed Approach across youth-serving systems and
label: H4

text: communities means all people at all levels of the system:
label: H4

text: Realize the prevalence and impact of trauma on youth, families,
label: H4

text: Recognize the signs of trauma in those they serve.
label: H4

text: Respond by integrating knowledge of trauma into policies,
label: H4

text: Resist re-traumatizing youth and families by creating environments
label: H4

text: that mimic past trauma, cause additional trauma, and compromise
label: H4

text: be ways of coping with trauma (e.g.
label: BODY

text: is the shared responsibility of all
label: BODY

text: Why is a Trauma-Informed Approach Critical to Supporting Youth?
label: H4

text: Minimizes risk for causing additional harm.
label: H4

text: Build Trauma-Informed Knowledge and Skills for
label: H4

text: Involve Youth and Familiesfor your content description 4
label: H4

text: What are the Core Components of a Trauma-Informed Approach?
label: H4

text: Build Trauma-Informed Knowledge and Skills fontent
label: H4

text: Community stakeholders, leaders, and staff across youth-serving systems are
label: H4

text: educated about trauma and its impact and trauma-informed practices.
label: H4

text: Includes education about particular traumatic experiences and impact for youth,
label: H4

text: Youth and families receive education about trauma and its impact.
label: H4

text: Develop safe and supportive environments and relationships:
label: H4

text: - Ensure youth and families of color are consistently treated fairly and respectfully.
label: BODY

text: - Minimize potential triggers in the environment.
label: BODY

text: - Intervene to address negative comments/perceptions based on race.
label: BODY

text: - Employ staff with similar backgrounds to the youth and families served.
label: BODY

text: Screen for trauma (including racial trauma) and assess for impact.
label: H4

text: Plans for youth consider ways to address trauma (e.g., behavioral health
label: H4

text: treatment plans, Individualized Education Plans, plans to support
label: H4

text: Youth have access to trauma-specific mental health interventions when
label: H4

text: Interventions are adapted to meet the needs of youth and families of color.
label: H4

text: Include youth and families on agency boards, advisory groups, working groups,
label: H4

text: and other decision-making bodies in youth-serving systems.
label: H4

text: Adopt formal mechanisms for seeking regular input from youth and families.
label: H4

text: Involve youth with similar life experiences in your programming.
label: H4

text: Develop a mission and vision statement that includes a commitment to a trauma-
label: H4

text: informed approach and meeting the specific needs of youth of color.
label: H4

text: Ensure the system responds promptly to acts of discrimination, harassment,
label: H4

text: Review policies and practices regularly to ensure full alignment with the mission
label: H4

text: and goals of a trauma-informed approach (include youth, families, staff).
label: H4

text: Provide cross-system learning, skills-building, and resource sharing related to
label: H4

text: Ensure consistent level of understanding and support for youth of color across
label: H4

text: Promote consistent policies and practices across youth-serving systems (e.g.,
label: H4

text: non-discrimination policies; practices to support positive youth development).
label: H4

text: Create partnerships with community members who specialize in working with
label: H4

text: Next steps for leaders for your own subheadline
label: H4

text: “Trauma is a fact of life. It does not, however, have to be a life
label: H4

text: sentence. Not only can trauma be healed, but with appropriate
label: H4

text: guidance and support, it can be transformative . . . How we
label: H4

text: handle trauma (as individuals, communities and societies)
label: H4

text: greatly influences the quality of our lives.”
